so that its state can be observed

inlineContent.text: This helper is an alternative to observing the view store manually on your view, which requires
the boilerplate of a custom initializer.
For example, the following view, which manually observes the store it is handed by constructing
a view store in its initializer:
…can be written more simply using
There may be times where the slightly more verbose style of observing a store is preferred
instead of using
When
wraps complex views the Swift compiler can quickly become bogged
down, leading to degraded compiler performance and diagnostics. If you are experiencing
such instability you should consider manually setting up observation with an
property as described above.
Sometimes you may want to observe the state in a store in a context that is not a view
builder. In such cases
will not work since it is intended only for
SwiftUI views.
An example of this is interfacing with SwiftUI’s
protocol, which uses a separate
instead of
. In this case you must use an
Note that it is highly discouraged for you to observe
all
of your root store’s state.
It is almost never needed and will cause many view recomputations leading to poor
performance. This is why we construct a separate
type that holds onto only the
state that the view needs for rendering. See
for more information on this
topic.
If your view does not need access to any state in the store and only needs to be able to send
actions, then you should consider not using
at all. Instead, you can send
actions to a
in a lightweight way like so:

abstract.text: Initializes a structure that transforms a store into an observable view store in order to
compute views from equatable store state.
Initializes a structure that transforms a
into an observable
in order
to compute bindings and views from state.
The Composable Architecture (TCA, for short) is a library for building applications in a consistent
and understandable way, with composition, testing, and ergonomics in mind. It can be used in
SwiftUI, UIKit, and more, and on any Apple platform (iOS, macOS, tvOS, and watchOS).
A view that safely unwraps a store of optional state in order to show one of two views.
Integrating the Composable Architecture into a SwiftUI application.
A navigation stack that is driven by a store.

A
is an object that can observe state changes and send actions. They are most
commonly used in views, such as SwiftUI views, UIView or UIViewController, but they can be used
anywhere it makes sense to observe state or send actions.
Initializes a structure that transforms a
into an observable
in order
to compute bindings and views from state.
A store represents the runtime that powers the application. It is the object that you will pass
around to views that need to interact with the application.
